title: Ineffective Coping Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing ineffective coping, focusing on assessment of maladaptive coping mechanisms, development of healthy coping strategies, and promotion of psychological well-being in patients experiencing stress, crisis, or difficulty adapting to life changes.

assessments.title: Coping Assessment
points: Assess current coping strategies and their effectiveness
Evaluate history of coping with previous stressors
Identify maladaptive coping mechanisms (substance use, avoidance, aggression)
Assess for signs of emotional distress (anxiety, depression, irritability)
Evaluate impact of coping difficulties on daily functioning
Assess problem-solving abilities and decision-making skills
Identify strengths and resources that can support adaptive coping
assessments.description: Comprehensive coping assessment helps identify specific maladaptive patterns and potential areas for intervention to improve coping effectiveness

assessments.title: Stress and Stressor Assessment
points: Identify current stressors (acute and chronic)
Assess patient's perception of stressors and their significance
Evaluate recent life changes or transitions
Assess for traumatic experiences
Identify cultural factors influencing stress perception and coping
Evaluate physical manifestations of stress (sleep disturbance, appetite changes)
Assess for suicidal ideation or self-harm behaviors related to overwhelming stress
assessments.description: Stressor assessment helps identify the nature, intensity, and impact of stressors affecting the patient's ability to cope effectively

assessments.title: Support System Assessment
points: Assess availability and quality of social support
Evaluate family relationships and dynamics
Identify supportive individuals in patient's life
Assess willingness to utilize support systems
Evaluate spiritual or religious resources
Identify community resources available to patient
Assess barriers to accessing support
assessments.description: Support system assessment helps identify resources that can be mobilized to enhance coping abilities and provide emotional support

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Ineffective Coping related to inadequate coping skills and overwhelming stressors as evidenced by inability to meet basic needs, verbalization of inability to cope, and use of maladaptive coping strategies
relatedFactors: Disturbance in pattern of appraisal of threat
Inadequate level of confidence in ability to cope
Inadequate opportunity to prepare for stressor
definingCharacteristics: Destructive behavior toward self or others

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Anxiety related to situational crisis and stress as evidenced by expressed concerns and increased tension

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved coping strategies when dealing with stressors
indicators: Identifies ineffective coping behaviors
Demonstrates use of at least two effective coping strategies
Verbalizes decreased feelings of being overwhelmed
Meets basic needs and role responsibilities
Utilizes appropriate support systems

goals.statement: Patient will develop a sustainable plan for managing ongoing stressors
indicators: Identifies personal strengths and resources
Demonstrates effective problem-solving skills
Establishes realistic goals for stress management
Incorporates stress-reduction techniques into daily routine
Maintains adaptive functioning in daily life despite stressors

interventions.title: Coping Enhancement
actions: Assist patient in identifying personal strengths and resources
Teach specific coping skills (deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, mindfulness)
Help patient identify and challenge negative thought patterns
Encourage expression of feelings in appropriate ways
Assist in breaking down problems into manageable parts
Provide positive reinforcement for adaptive coping efforts
Teach stress management techniques
Assist in developing a crisis plan for overwhelming situations
rationales: Awareness of strengths builds confidence in coping abilities
Specific techniques provide concrete tools for managing stress
Cognitive restructuring improves stress appraisal and response
Emotional expression prevents buildup of distress
Breaking down problems reduces feeling overwhelmed
Positive reinforcement strengthens adaptive behaviors
Stress management techniques reduce physiological arousal
Crisis planning provides structure during overwhelming situations
interventions.frequency: Daily during acute phase, then 2-3 times weekly
specialConsiderations: Adapt interventions to patient's cultural background and beliefs
Consider developmental stage when selecting appropriate coping strategies
Modify approach based on patient's cognitive abilities and learning style

interventions.title: Support System Enhancement
actions: Assess barriers to utilizing support systems
Encourage reconnection with supportive individuals
Provide information about community resources and support groups
Facilitate family meetings to improve understanding and support
Teach effective communication skills for requesting help
Role-play difficult social interactions
Encourage gradual increase in social activities
Assist in developing plan for maintaining support network
rationales: Identifying barriers allows targeted interventions
Social connection provides emotional support and practical assistance
Community resources extend support beyond immediate circle
Family involvement improves understanding and coordinated support
Communication skills improve ability to access support
Role-playing builds confidence in social interactions
Gradual exposure prevents social overwhelm
Ongoing support planning prevents relapse of ineffective coping
specialConsiderations: Respect patient's autonomy in choosing support resources
Consider cultural factors influencing help-seeking behaviors
Be sensitive to family dynamics that may complicate support

evaluations.statement: Has patient demonstrated improved coping strategies?
expectedOutcomes: Identifies ineffective coping behaviors and their consequences
Demonstrates use of effective coping strategies when stressed
Reports decreased feelings of being overwhelmed
Successfully meets basic needs and role responsibilities
Appropriately utilizes support systems
Shows reduced physical symptoms of stress
evaluationMethods: Observation of coping behaviors during stressful situations
Assessment of role functioning and basic needs management
Monitoring of physical symptoms related to stress

evaluations.statement: Has patient developed a sustainable plan for managing ongoing stressors?
expectedOutcomes: Articulates personal strengths and resources
Demonstrates effective problem-solving when facing challenges
Follows established plan for stress management
Incorporates stress-reduction techniques into daily routine
Maintains adaptive functioning despite presence of stressors
Expresses confidence in ability to manage future stressors
evaluationMethods: Self-monitoring logs of stress management activities
Follow-up assessment of functioning in daily roles
Patient self-efficacy rating for stress management

references.author: Skinner EA, Edge K, Altman J, Sherwood H
references.title: Searching for the structure of coping: a review and critique of category systems for classifying ways of coping

notes: Consider referral to specialized mental health services for patients with persistent maladaptive coping that significantly impairs functioning
timeFrame: Initial intervention 2-3 weeks, ongoing support 4-8 weeks

title: Anxiety Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing anxiety, focusing on assessment of anxiety severity and triggers, implementation of pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions, and development of anxiety management skills in patients experiencing various anxiety disorders or situational anxiety.

assessments.title: Anxiety Assessment
points: Assess level of anxiety using standardized tools (GAD-7, Hamilton Anxiety Scale)
Evaluate physical manifestations of anxiety (tachycardia, hyperventilation, tremors)
Assess cognitive symptoms (worry, fear, catastrophizing, rumination)
Identify behavioral responses (avoidance, restlessness, irritability)
Determine impact of anxiety on daily functioning and relationships
Assess for panic attacks and their frequency, duration, and intensity
Evaluate for comorbid conditions (depression, substance use, medical conditions)
assessments.description: Comprehensive anxiety assessment helps determine the severity, manifestations, and impact of anxiety to guide appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Trigger and Pattern Assessment
points: Identify specific anxiety triggers (situations, thoughts, physical sensations)
Assess patterns of anxiety occurrence (time of day, context, preceding events)
Evaluate patient's awareness of anxiety triggers
Assess avoidance behaviors related to anxiety
Identify early warning signs of escalating anxiety
Evaluate safety concerns related to anxiety (driving avoidance, agoraphobia)
Assess impact of anxiety on sleep patterns
assessments.description: Trigger assessment helps identify specific factors that precipitate or exacerbate anxiety, allowing for targeted interventions and prevention strategies

assessments.title: Coping and Resource Assessment
points: Assess current coping strategies for anxiety management
Evaluate effectiveness of previous treatments for anxiety
Identify patient's knowledge about anxiety and its management
Assess willingness to learn and implement new anxiety management techniques
Evaluate support system understanding of anxiety
Assess medication use, including prescribed anxiolytics and self-medication
Identify strengths and resources that can support anxiety management
assessments.description: Coping assessment helps identify existing strategies, knowledge gaps, and resources that can be utilized or enhanced to improve anxiety management

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Anxiety related to situational crisis, threat to self-concept, and stress as evidenced by expressed worry, increased tension, and physiological symptoms
Ineffective Coping related to high degree of threat as evidenced by inability to meet role expectations and destructive behavior toward self
relatedFactors: Disturbance in pattern of tension release
Inadequate level of perception of control

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate reduced anxiety as evidenced by decreased physical and psychological symptoms
indicators: Reports decreased subjective feelings of anxiety
Demonstrates normalized vital signs during previously anxiety-provoking situations
Shows reduced physical manifestations of anxiety (tremors, hyperventilation)
Verbalizes reduced worry and rumination
Demonstrates improved concentration and decision-making

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate effective use of anxiety management techniques
indicators: Identifies personal anxiety triggers and early warning signs
Demonstrates at least three anxiety reduction techniques
Implements anxiety management strategies before anxiety escalates
Reduces avoidance behaviors related to anxiety
Reports improved ability to function despite presence of anxiety

interventions.title: Anxiety Reduction
actions: Create a calm, quiet environment with minimal stimulation
Use a calm, reassuring approach during interactions
Teach and assist with relaxation techniques (deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, guided imagery)
Administer anti-anxiety medications as prescribed
Monitor for and manage medication side effects
Provide accurate information about anxiety and its management
Maintain consistent caregivers when possible
Use simple, clear communication during periods of high anxiety
rationales: Calm environment reduces external stimuli that may trigger anxiety
Calm approach prevents interpersonal transmission of anxiety
Relaxation techniques activate parasympathetic nervous system
Medications reduce acute anxiety symptoms when indicated
Monitoring prevents adverse effects that may increase anxiety
Accurate information reduces fear of the unknown
Consistency provides security and reduces uncertainty
Simple communication reduces cognitive demands during anxiety
interventions.frequency: Every 2-4 hours during acute anxiety; daily for ongoing management
specialConsiderations: Avoid benzodiazepines for patients with substance use disorders when possible
Consider cultural factors that may influence anxiety expression and management
Adapt relaxation techniques for patients with trauma histories who may find certain approaches triggering

interventions.title: Cognitive Behavioral Techniques
actions: Assist in identifying and challenging catastrophic thinking patterns
Teach cognitive restructuring techniques
Implement systematic desensitization for specific phobias
Develop hierarchy of anxiety-provoking situations for gradual exposure
Teach mindfulness-based approaches to manage worry
Implement thought-stopping techniques for rumination
Assist in developing realistic appraisals of threatening situations
Teach problem-solving skills for manageable stressors
rationales: Identifying catastrophic thinking interrupts anxiety cycle
Cognitive restructuring replaces anxiety-provoking thoughts with realistic ones
Systematic desensitization gradually reduces phobic responses
Gradual exposure builds confidence and reduces avoidance
Mindfulness reduces rumination and worry
Thought-stopping interrupts repetitive anxiety-producing thoughts
Realistic appraisals reduce threat perception
Problem-solving provides sense of control over stressors
interventions.frequency: Daily during acute phase; 2-3 times weekly for maintenance
specialConsiderations: Ensure patient has adequate coping skills before implementing exposure techniques
Modify cognitive approaches based on patient's educational level and cognitive abilities
Consider combining with medication for severe anxiety

interventions.title: Patient Education
actions: Educate about the physiology of anxiety and fight-or-flight response
Teach about the relationship between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
Provide information about medication action, timing, and side effects
Instruct on identifying early warning signs of anxiety escalation
Teach sleep hygiene practices to improve anxiety-related insomnia
Provide guidance on lifestyle factors affecting anxiety (caffeine, exercise, nutrition)
Develop a written anxiety management plan
Educate family/support persons about helpful responses to patient's anxiety
rationales: Understanding physiology normalizes and demystifies anxiety symptoms
Cognitive-behavioral model provides framework for intervention
Medication knowledge improves adherence and effectiveness
Early recognition allows prompt intervention before escalation
Improved sleep reduces vulnerability to anxiety
Lifestyle modifications reduce physiological triggers for anxiety
Written plan provides structure during high anxiety periods
Educated support persons provide more effective assistance
interventions.frequency: Daily during hospitalization; reinforced at follow-up appointments

expectedOutcomes: Reports decreased subjective anxiety levels
Demonstrates reduced physical symptoms of anxiety
Shows improved vital signs during anxiety-provoking situations
Verbalizes decreased worry and rumination
Demonstrates improved concentration and decision-making
Reports improved sleep quality
evaluationMethods: Vital sign monitoring during stressful situations
Patient self-report of worry and thought patterns
Observation of concentration and task completion

evaluations.statement: Is patient effectively using anxiety management techniques?
expectedOutcomes: Correctly identifies personal anxiety triggers
Demonstrates effective use of relaxation techniques
Implements anxiety management strategies before escalation
Shows reduced avoidance of anxiety-provoking situations
Reports improved functioning despite presence of anxiety
Demonstrates cognitive restructuring of anxious thoughts

references.author: Bandelow B, Michaelis S, Wedekind D
references.title: Treatment of anxiety disorders

references.author: Hofmann SG, Sawyer AT, Witt AA, Oh D
references.title: The effect of mindfulness-based therapy on anxiety and depression: A meta-analytic review

notes: Consider referral to psychiatric services for patients with severe anxiety disorders not responding to initial interventions or those with comorbid conditions requiring specialized treatment
timeFrame: Acute management 1-2 weeks, ongoing management 4-8 weeks

title: Fear Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing fear, focusing on assessment of specific fears and their impact, implementation of therapeutic interventions to reduce fear responses, and development of coping strategies for patients experiencing specific phobias, trauma-related fears, or situational fears.

assessments.title: Fear Assessment
points: Assess specific fear trigger(s) and context
Evaluate intensity of fear response using subjective rating scales (0-10)
Assess physical manifestations of fear (tachycardia, hyperventilation, trembling)
Identify cognitive components (catastrophic thoughts, perceived threat)
Evaluate behavioral responses (escape, avoidance, freezing, fighting)
Assess impact of fear on daily functioning and quality of life
Determine onset and development of fear (trauma-related, learned, inherited)
assessments.description: Comprehensive fear assessment helps identify specific fear triggers, manifestations, and impact to guide appropriate interventions and exposure planning

assessments.title: Safety and Risk Assessment
points: Assess for presence of real versus perceived danger
Evaluate risk of harm to self or others related to fear response
Assess for suicidal ideation related to overwhelming fear
Identify safety behaviors and their reinforcing effects
Evaluate degree of functional impairment due to avoidance
Assess for trauma history that may complicate fear response
Identify environmental factors that increase or decrease perceived safety
assessments.description: Safety assessment helps distinguish between realistic and excessive fears, identify risk factors, and develop appropriate safety interventions

assessments.title: Coping and Resource Assessment
points: Assess current coping strategies for managing fear
Evaluate effectiveness of previous treatments for fear
Identify patient's knowledge about fear responses and management
Assess willingness to engage in exposure-based interventions
Evaluate support system understanding of fear response
Assess medication use related to fear management
Identify strengths and resources that can support fear management
assessments.description: Coping assessment helps identify existing strategies, knowledge gaps, and resources that can be utilized or enhanced to improve fear management

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Fear related to identifiable threat or danger as evidenced by increased tension, apprehension, and physiological arousal
relatedFactors: Identifiable threat or danger (real or perceived)
definingCharacteristics: Focus narrowed to source of fear
Physiological responses (increased heart rate, respiratory rate)
Expressions of being scared or frightened

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Impaired Social Interaction related to fear and anxiety as evidenced by discomfort in social situations and decreased social involvement
relatedFactors: Limited physical mobility due to fear
definingCharacteristics: Family report of changes in interaction

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate reduced fear response when exposed to fear trigger
indicators: Reports decreased subjective fear rating (reduction of at least 3 points on 0-10 scale)
Demonstrates decreased physiological arousal during exposure
Verbalizes more realistic appraisal of threat
Shows reduced avoidance behaviors
Maintains presence in feared situation for increasing periods

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate effective use of fear management techniques
indicators: Identifies early warning signs of fear response
Implements at least three fear reduction techniques
Uses cognitive restructuring for fear-inducing thoughts
Gradually approaches feared situations using learned techniques
Reports improved ability to function despite presence of fear

interventions.title: Anxiety/Fear Reduction
actions: Create a safe, supportive environment
Use calm, reassuring approach during interactions
Teach relaxation techniques (deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation)
Administer anti-anxiety medications as prescribed for severe fear responses
Provide accurate information about feared object/situation
Teach grounding techniques for acute fear responses
Implement distraction techniques when appropriate
Provide opportunities to discuss fears in a non-judgmental environment
rationales: Safe environment establishes foundation for fear reduction work
Calm approach prevents interpersonal transmission of fear/anxiety
Relaxation techniques reduce physiological arousal associated with fear
Medications may be necessary for severe fear that prevents therapeutic work
Accurate information corrects misconceptions about feared stimulus
Grounding reconnects patient to present safety during acute fear
Distraction temporarily reduces fear to manageable levels
Discussion allows cognitive processing of fear in safe context
interventions.frequency: Every 2-4 hours during acute fear; daily for ongoing management
specialConsiderations: Avoid forcing exposure to feared stimulus before adequate coping skills are developed
Consider trauma history when implementing fear reduction techniques
Adapt approach based on type of fear (phobic vs. trauma-related)

interventions.title: Systematic Desensitization/Exposure
actions: Develop hierarchy of feared situations from least to most frightening
Teach coping skills to use during exposure (relaxation, cognitive techniques)
Begin exposure with least frightening item on hierarchy
Provide support and encouragement during exposure sessions
Gradually increase exposure duration and intensity
Process thoughts and feelings after each exposure
Prevent escape or avoidance during planned exposure
Assign homework for real-world practice between sessions
rationales: Hierarchy provides structured approach to gradually face fears
Coping skills provide tools to manage fear during exposure
Starting with least frightening builds confidence and success
Support reduces likelihood of overwhelming fear during exposure
Gradual progression builds tolerance to fear stimulus
Processing consolidates learning from exposure experience
Preventing escape allows habituation to occur
Homework generalizes skills to real-world situations
interventions.frequency: 2-3 times weekly for structured exposure; daily for self-directed practice
specialConsiderations: Ensure patient has adequate coping skills before implementing exposure
Monitor for signs of overwhelming distress during exposure
Consider imaginal exposure for situations that cannot be recreated safely

interventions.title: Cognitive Restructuring
actions: Help identify fear-producing thoughts and beliefs
Assist in evaluating evidence for and against fearful thoughts
Teach patient to challenge catastrophic thinking
Develop more realistic alternative thoughts
Practice cognitive reframing of feared situations
Implement thought records to track and challenge fear-based thoughts
Teach recognition of cognitive distortions that maintain fear
Reinforce realistic thinking about feared object/situation
rationales: Identifying thoughts reveals cognitive basis of fear
Evidence evaluation promotes more balanced thinking
Challenging catastrophic thinking reduces perceived threat
Alternative thoughts provide replacement for fear-producing cognitions
Reframing changes perception of feared situations
Thought records increase awareness of automatic fear thoughts
Recognizing distortions is first step in correcting them
Reinforcement strengthens realistic thinking patterns
interventions.frequency: Daily during acute phase; 2-3 times weekly for maintenance

expectedOutcomes: Reports decreased subjective fear ratings
Demonstrates reduced physiological arousal during exposure
Verbalizes more realistic appraisal of threat
Shows reduced avoidance behaviors
Maintains presence in feared situation for increasing periods
Reports decreased interference with daily functioning
evaluationMethods: Physiological assessment during exposure (heart rate, respiration)

evaluations.statement: Is patient effectively using fear management techniques?
expectedOutcomes: Correctly identifies early warning signs of fear response
Demonstrates effective use of relaxation techniques during fear
Implements cognitive restructuring for fear-inducing thoughts
Gradually approaches feared situations using learned techniques
Reports improved ability to function despite presence of fear
Uses fear management strategies independently
evaluationMethods: Observation of technique use during exposure
Review of thought records or cognitive exercises

references.title: Maximizing exposure therapy: An inhibitory learning approach

title: Disturbed Body Image Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing disturbed body image, focusing on assessment of body image perceptions and distortions, implementation of therapeutic interventions to improve body acceptance, and development of healthy self-concept in patients experiencing body image disturbance due to physical changes, eating disorders, or psychological factors.

assessments.title: Body Image Perception Assessment
points: Assess patient's perception of body appearance, function, and integrity
Evaluate for presence of body image distortions using standardized tools
Identify specific body areas or functions of concern
Assess degree of preoccupation with perceived flaws
Evaluate impact of body image concerns on daily functioning
Assess for body-checking or body-avoidance behaviors
Determine onset and development of body image concerns
assessments.description: Comprehensive body image assessment helps identify specific perceptions, distortions, and their impact to guide appropriate therapeutic interventions

assessments.title: Physical and Functional Assessment
points: Assess for actual physical changes or differences (surgical changes, weight changes, disfigurement)
Evaluate functional limitations related to physical condition
Assess self-care abilities and limitations
Identify adaptive equipment or prosthetics being used
Evaluate hygiene and grooming practices
Assess nutritional status and eating patterns
Identify physical symptoms related to body image concerns (pain, fatigue)
assessments.description: Physical assessment helps identify actual changes or limitations that may be contributing to body image disturbance and areas requiring adaptation or rehabilitation

assessments.title: Psychosocial Assessment
points: Assess emotional response to body image (shame, disgust, anxiety, depression)
Evaluate impact on social relationships and interactions
Assess for social isolation or avoidance due to body image concerns
Identify cultural, societal, and family influences on body image
Evaluate sexual self-concept and intimacy concerns
Assess for comorbid conditions (eating disorders, depression, anxiety, OCD)
Identify coping strategies used to manage body image distress
assessments.description: Psychosocial assessment helps identify emotional and social impacts of body image disturbance and factors that may maintain negative body image

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Disturbed Body Image related to altered body function or appearance as evidenced by negative feelings about body and preoccupation with change or loss
definingCharacteristics: Verbalization of negative feelings about body
Perceptions that reflect altered view of body appearance
Feelings of helplessness or hopelessness about physical condition

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Situational Low Self-Esteem related to disturbed body image as evidenced by negative self-evaluation and verbalized negative feelings about self
relatedFactors: Loss of valued body part or function
definingCharacteristics: Evaluates self as unable to deal with situations or events

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved body image acceptance
indicators: Verbalizes more realistic perception of body appearance and function
Demonstrates decreased preoccupation with perceived flaws
Expresses positive aspects of physical self
Demonstrates appropriate self-care and grooming
Engages in social activities despite body image concerns

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate effective coping with body changes or perceived flaws
indicators: Uses adaptive equipment or techniques effectively
Implements healthy self-care behaviors
Demonstrates reduced body-checking or avoidance behaviors
Uses positive self-talk regarding body
Participates in activities previously avoided due to body image

interventions.title: Body Image Enhancement
actions: Establish therapeutic relationship based on acceptance and respect
Assist in identifying positive body attributes and functions
Help differentiate between changeable and unchangeable body characteristics
Teach realistic self-assessment techniques
Provide accurate information about normal body variations
Assist in identifying unrealistic standards or expectations
Encourage expression of feelings about body and self
Facilitate grieving process for actual body changes or losses
rationales: Therapeutic relationship provides foundation for body image work
Identifying positives balances focus on perceived flaws
Differentiation helps direct energy toward achievable changes
Realistic assessment corrects distorted perceptions
Accurate information normalizes body variations
Identifying unrealistic standards allows challenging of internalized ideals
Emotional expression facilitates processing of body-related feelings
Grieving acknowledges real losses and facilitates adaptation
interventions.frequency: Daily during acute phase; 2-3 times weekly for maintenance
specialConsiderations: Adapt approach based on cause of body image disturbance (illness, trauma, eating disorder)
Consider developmental stage and its impact on body image concerns
Be sensitive to cultural factors influencing body image ideals

interventions.title: Cognitive Restructuring
actions: Help identify negative thoughts about body and appearance
Teach recognition of cognitive distortions related to body image
Assist in challenging body-related cognitive distortions
Develop more balanced and realistic alternative thoughts
Implement thought records to track and challenge negative body thoughts
Teach mindfulness-based approaches to body image thoughts
Practice cognitive reframing of body-related situations
Reduce all-or-nothing thinking about appearance
rationales: Identifying thoughts reveals cognitive basis of body image disturbance
Recognizing distortions is first step in correcting them
Challenging distortions promotes more accurate self-perception
Alternative thoughts replace negative body-related cognitions
Thought records increase awareness of automatic negative thoughts
Mindfulness reduces overidentification with body-related thoughts
Reframing changes perception of body-related situations
Reducing dichotomous thinking promotes more nuanced body perception
interventions.frequency: Daily during acute phase; 2-3 times weekly for maintenance

interventions.title: Self-Esteem Enhancement
actions: Encourage identification of strengths and positive attributes beyond appearance
Assist in developing identity based on multiple aspects of self
Teach positive self-talk and affirmations
Encourage participation in activities that provide sense of accomplishment
Facilitate connections with supportive others
Provide feedback about positive behaviors and characteristics
Assist in setting realistic, achievable goals
Teach assertiveness skills to counter negative comments from others
rationales: Identifying strengths broadens self-concept beyond body image
Multifaceted identity reduces overemphasis on appearance
Positive self-talk counters negative internal dialogue
Accomplishment builds confidence in non-appearance domains
Supportive connections provide validation beyond appearance
Positive feedback reinforces non-appearance-based self-worth
Achieving goals builds self-efficacy and confidence
Assertiveness protects self-esteem from external criticism

expectedOutcomes: Verbalizes more realistic perception of body
Demonstrates decreased preoccupation with perceived flaws
Expresses positive aspects of physical self
Demonstrates appropriate self-care and grooming
Engages in social activities despite body image concerns
Reports decreased distress related to body image
evaluationMethods: Assessment of time spent on body preoccupation

evaluations.statement: Is patient effectively coping with body changes or perceived flaws?
expectedOutcomes: Uses adaptive equipment or techniques effectively
Implements healthy self-care behaviors
Demonstrates reduced body-checking or avoidance behaviors
Uses positive self-talk regarding body
Participates in activities previously avoided due to body image
Demonstrates flexibility in coping with body-related situations

references.author: Cash TF, Smolak L
references.title: Body Image: A Handbook of Science, Practice, and Prevention

references.author: Alleva JM, Sheeran P, Webb TL, Martijn C, Miles E
references.title: A Meta-Analytic Review of Stand-Alone Interventions to Improve Body Image

references.author: Tylka TL, Wood-Barcalow NL
references.title: What is and what is not positive body image? Conceptual foundations and construct definition

notes: Consider referral to specialized services for patients with severe body image disturbance, especially those with comorbid eating disorders or body dysmorphic disorder
timeFrame: Initial intervention 3-4 weeks, ongoing management 8-12 weeks

title: Grieving Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for supporting the grieving process, focusing on assessment of grief reactions, facilitation of healthy grieving, and prevention of complicated grief in patients experiencing loss through death, significant life changes, or other losses.

assessments.title: Grief Response Assessment
points: Assess type and significance of loss experienced
Evaluate current stage or manifestations of grief
Identify emotional responses (sadness, anger, guilt, relief)
Assess cognitive responses (disbelief, preoccupation with loss, confusion)
Evaluate behavioral responses (crying, searching, social withdrawal)
Assess physical manifestations (sleep disturbance, appetite changes, fatigue)
Identify spiritual or existential concerns related to loss
assessments.description: Comprehensive grief assessment helps identify the nature and manifestations of grief to guide appropriate supportive interventions

assessments.title: Risk Assessment
points: Assess for risk factors for complicated grief
Evaluate for signs of complicated or prolonged grief disorder
Assess for suicidal ideation or intent
Identify maladaptive coping mechanisms (substance use, risk-taking behaviors)
Evaluate impact of grief on daily functioning and self-care
Assess for co-occurring mental health conditions
Identify previous losses and grief responses
assessments.description: Risk assessment helps identify factors that may complicate the grieving process and require specialized intervention

assessments.title: Support and Resource Assessment
points: Assess availability and quality of social support
Evaluate cultural and religious factors influencing grief expression
Identify personal coping strengths and resources
Assess knowledge about grief process and expectations
Evaluate financial or practical concerns related to loss
Identify community resources available for grief support
Assess family functioning and impact of loss on family system
assessments.description: Support assessment helps identify resources that can facilitate healthy grieving and areas where additional support may be needed

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Grieving related to loss as evidenced by emotional distress, preoccupation with loss, and altered functioning
relatedFactors: Loss of significant object (job, home, possessions)
Loss of physiological function or body part
Loss of developmental or life stage
Loss of expected future or possibilities
definingCharacteristics: Questioning the meaning of life or death

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Complicated Grieving related to sudden or unexpected nature of loss
definingCharacteristics: Avoidance of reminders of the loss
Persistent feelings of shock or disbelief

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate progression through the grieving process
indicators: Acknowledges the reality of the loss
Expresses grief-related emotions appropriately
Identifies and uses effective coping strategies
Maintains adequate self-care despite grief
Begins to adjust to life without the lost person/object
goals.timeframe: Ongoing, with regular assessment of progress

goals.statement: Patient will maintain or re-establish functional daily living patterns
indicators: Maintains adequate nutrition and hydration
Establishes healthy sleep patterns
Participates in necessary daily activities
Engages in appropriate social interactions
Returns to work/school/normal roles as appropriate

interventions.title: Grief Work Facilitation
actions: Establish therapeutic relationship based on empathy and presence
Create safe environment for expression of grief emotions
Normalize grief reactions and educate about grief process
Assist in identifying and expressing feelings about the loss
Encourage reminiscence and life review related to the loss
Support cultural and religious mourning practices
Facilitate identification of personal meaning of the loss
Assist in identifying and resolving secondary losses
rationales: Therapeutic relationship provides foundation for grief work
Safe environment allows authentic grief expression
Normalization reduces fear about grief reactions
Emotional expression is essential for grief processing
Reminiscence helps integrate the loss into life narrative
Cultural practices provide structure and meaning to mourning
Finding meaning facilitates integration of the loss
Addressing secondary losses acknowledges full impact of primary loss
interventions.frequency: Daily during acute grief; 1-2 times weekly for ongoing support
specialConsiderations: Adapt approach based on cultural background and beliefs about death/loss
Consider developmental stage and its impact on grief understanding
Respect individual timing and style of grieving

interventions.title: Emotional Support
actions: Provide non-judgmental listening and presence
Validate grief emotions without minimizing or rushing
Use touch appropriately if culturally acceptable
Assist in identifying and challenging unhelpful grief beliefs
Provide hope without false reassurance
Support patient through anniversary dates and significant occasions
Encourage self-compassion during difficult grief moments
Provide anticipatory guidance about grief triggers and waves
rationales: Non-judgmental presence allows authentic grief expression
Validation acknowledges the reality and importance of grief
Appropriate touch provides comfort and connection
Challenging unhelpful beliefs reduces unnecessary suffering
Hope acknowledges possibility of healing without denying pain
Significant dates often trigger increased grief intensity
Self-compassion reduces secondary suffering during grief
Anticipatory guidance normalizes grief fluctuations
specialConsiderations: Be aware of personal reactions to patient's grief
Avoid platitudes or statements that minimize the loss
Recognize that grief is unique to each individual

interventions.title: Support System Enhancement
actions: Assess current support system and its effectiveness
Identify barriers to utilizing available support
Provide information about grief support groups
Facilitate family communication about the loss
Educate family/friends about helpful responses to grief
Connect patient with spiritual support if desired
Provide information about community bereavement resources
Facilitate referrals to specialized grief counseling if needed
rationales: Assessment identifies support gaps and strengths
Addressing barriers increases likelihood of support utilization
Support groups provide validation and normalization from peers
Family communication prevents isolation and misunderstanding
Education helps others provide more effective support

title: Disturbed Thought Processes Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing disturbed thought processes, focusing on assessment of thought content and perceptual disturbances, implementation of therapeutic interventions to improve reality testing, and promotion of safety and functioning in patients experiencing psychosis, severe cognitive distortions, or thought disorders.

assessments.title: Thought Process Assessment
points: Assess form of thought (flight of ideas, tangentiality, circumstantiality, loose associations)
Evaluate thought content (delusions, obsessions, phobias, suicidal/homicidal ideation)
Assess for perceptual disturbances (hallucinations, illusions)
Evaluate insight and judgment
Assess orientation to person, place, time, and situation
Evaluate concentration and attention span
Assess abstract thinking and reasoning abilities
assessments.description: Comprehensive thought process assessment helps identify specific disturbances in thought form, content, and perception to guide appropriate interventions

assessments.title: Safety Assessment
points: Assess for danger to self or others related to thought disturbance
Evaluate ability to maintain basic self-care and safety
Assess for command hallucinations or delusions involving harm
Identify environmental hazards for patient with impaired judgment
Evaluate medication adherence and understanding
Assess ability to recognize warning signs of decompensation
Identify previous patterns of psychotic episodes and effective interventions
assessments.description: Safety assessment helps identify risks related to thought disturbances and develop appropriate safety interventions

assessments.title: Functional Assessment
points: Assess impact of thought disturbance on activities of daily living
Evaluate effect on social functioning and relationships
Assess ability to communicate needs effectively
Evaluate impact on occupational or educational functioning
Assess level of distress caused by thought disturbances
Identify strengths and intact abilities despite thought disturbance
Evaluate support system understanding and response to thought disturbances
assessments.description: Functional assessment helps identify areas of impairment requiring intervention and preserved abilities that can be leveraged in treatment

interventions.title: Thought Disturbance Management
actions: Create a calm, structured environment with reduced stimulation
Maintain reality-based interactions using clear, concrete communication
Avoid challenging delusions directly; focus on feelings underlying delusions
Redirect from delusional or hallucinatory content to reality-based topics
Assist in distinguishing between real and unreal perceptions
Provide reality orientation as appropriate (person, place, time)
Administer antipsychotic medications as prescribed
Monitor for and manage medication side effects
rationales: Calm environment reduces sensory overload that can worsen thought disturbances
Clear communication reduces misinterpretation and confusion
Challenging delusions directly often increases defensiveness
Redirection shifts focus to reality-based content
Distinguishing real from unreal improves reality testing
Reality orientation reinforces accurate perception of environment
Antipsychotic medications reduce neurochemical basis of thought disturbances
Side effect management improves medication adherence and outcomes
specialConsiderations: Adjust approach based on patient's level of agitation and insight
Consider cultural beliefs that may influence interpretation of thought content
Recognize that some patients may require longer-term management of residual symptoms

interventions.title: Safety Management
actions: Implement appropriate level of observation based on risk assessment
Remove potential weapons or hazardous items from environment
Establish safety contract for reporting harmful thoughts or commands
Implement structured daily routine to reduce anxiety and confusion
Use de-escalation techniques for agitation related to thought disturbances
Administer PRN medications for acute agitation per protocol
Provide supervision during activities requiring judgment or safety awareness
Teach recognition of early warning signs of decompensation
rationales: Appropriate observation prevents harm while maintaining dignity
Environmental safety reduces access to means of harm
Safety contract establishes shared responsibility for safety
Structure reduces anxiety that can worsen thought disturbances
De-escalation prevents need for more restrictive interventions
PRN medications manage acute symptoms that threaten safety
Supervision compensates for impaired judgment
Early recognition allows prompt intervention before severe decompensation
specialConsiderations: Balance safety needs with least restrictive environment principles
Consider legal and ethical aspects of involuntary treatment if necessary
Involve family/support persons in safety planning when appropriate

interventions.title: Cognitive Skill Building
actions: Provide reality testing exercises for delusional beliefs
Teach cognitive behavioral techniques to manage hallucinations
Implement attention-focusing activities for distractibility
Provide simple, step-by-step instructions for tasks
Use written reminders and visual cues to support memory
Teach problem-solving framework for decision-making
Provide feedback about appropriate versus inappropriate behaviors
Practice social skills and communication in structured settings
rationales: Reality testing exercises strengthen connection to accurate perceptions
CBT techniques help manage responses to persistent symptoms
Attention activities improve concentration and focus
Simple instructions accommodate cognitive processing difficulties
Visual cues bypass verbal processing deficits
Problem-solving framework compensates for executive function deficits
Feedback clarifies social expectations and norms
Practice builds social skills affected by thought disturbances
